summary_points: 1. American Express' Q1 2025 net income increased 6% year-over-year to $2.6 billion, driven by premium customer spending.
2.  An EU advisory opinion (March 6, 2025) regarding interchange fee caps may negatively impact future revenues and partnerships.
3.  American Express settled a lawsuit (*B&R Supermarket, Inc. d/b/a Milam’s Market, et al. v. Visa Inc., et al.*) in principle as of March 31, 2025, pending final agreement and court approval.
1. On April 16th, 2025, Carnival Corporation and Carnival plc held their annual shareholder meetings, where all proposed director nominees were elected and all other proposals were approved.
2.  At the shareholder meetings, proxy votes were received for 967,256,171 shares.
3.  The filing shows significant variation in shareholder votes for director re-elections, ranging from approximately 713,556,673 votes for (Proposal 8) to 786,675,263 votes for (Proposal 6).

1. At Texas Instruments Incorporated's April 17, 2025, annual meeting, all board nominees were elected, though with varying levels of shareholder support ranging from 653,589,748 votes for Carrie Cox to 734,380,183 votes for Curtis Farmer.
2.  Shareholders voted against a proposal to permit a combined 10% of stockholders to call a special meeting by a margin of 425,922,191 votes against to 318,057,232 votes in favor.
3.  Shareholder approval for the board's proposal regarding advisory approval of executive compensation was relatively low, with 648,369,929 votes in favor versus 95,514,709 votes against.

1. On April 17, 2025, a US District Court ruled that Google's (a subsidiary of Alphabet Inc.) publisher tools violated antitrust laws, while its advertiser tools and acquisitions were deemed not anticompetitive; Google plans to appeal.
2.  No meaningful numerical comparisons were provided in this 8-K filing.
3. The court's decision, and Google's appeal, presents a future legal risk to Alphabet Inc., with potential financial penalties or changes to Google's business practices depending on the outcome.
1. HP Inc.'s 2025 annual meeting on April 14, 2025, resulted in the election of thirteen individuals to the Board of Directors, with each receiving over 97.5% of the votes cast.
2.  Ernst & Young LLP was ratified as HP Inc.'s independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending October 31, 2025, receiving 93.6% of the votes.
3. HP Inc.'s named executive officer compensation was approved by an advisory vote, with 93.7% of the shares present and entitled to vote approving the proposal.
1. On April 14, 2025, Monster Beverage Corporation director Gary P. Fayard announced his intention not to stand for reelection at the 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders.
2.  The filing is an 8-K Current Report, indicating a significant event occurred at Monster Beverage Corporation.
3. Mr. Fayard's departure is not due to any disagreement with the company, its management, the board, or any board committee; he will remain a director until the 2025 Annual Meeting.
